Fig. 1 Electrochemical energy conversion and storage applications of 2D MOFs. With their great structural tunability and large porosity, 2D MOF-based materials can serve as a future hotbed for applications in electrochemical energy storage. Fig. 2 Synthesis strategies of two-dimensional metal–organic frameworks. Fig. 3 Different strategies for 2D MOF design. 2D sheets can be constructed using woof and weft (weaving) (a) and chicken (fence) wiring (b) or by the perpendicular interpenetration of ladders [Ni(OBA)(L1)]·H2O [85], (c) using 1D structures. Another approach is the use of 2D nets to construct 2D sheets as presented in (d) which presents 2D parallel interpenetration in [Ag(TEB)- (CF3SO3)] or Borromean interpenetration of rings (e) as presented in 2D to the 2D parallel interpenetration of sheets in [Cu2(tmeda)2(Au(CN)2)3](ClO4) [86] (f). Fig. 4 (a) Illustration of the preparation method for Ni MOF NSs through interfacial reaction; (b) photograph of the Ni MOF nanosheets forming between the interface of two solutions and (c) TEM image of Ni MOF nanosheet. Graphical abstract In this comprehensive review, we present an all-encompassing perspective on the diverse aspects of 2D metal–organic framework-based materials from design strategies to fabrication and their use as electrode materials in Li-ion batteries. Two-dimensional (2D) metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are rapidly emerging as a unique class of mushrooming family of 2D materials offering distinctive features, such as hierarchical porosity, extensive surface area, easily available active sites, and versatile, adaptable structures. These promising characteristics have positioned them as highly appealing alternatives for a wide range of applications in energy storage technologies, including lithium batteries. Nevertheless, the poor conductivity and limited stability of 2D MOFs have limited their real applications in electrochemical energy storage. These limitations have therefore warranted ongoing research to enhance the performance of 2D MOFs. Given the significance of 2D MOF-based materials as an emerging class of advanced materials, a multitude of strategy has been devised to address these challenges such as synthesizing 2D conductive MOFs and derivatives along with 2D MOF hybridization. One promising approach involves the use of 2D MOF derivatives, including transition metal oxides, which due to their abundant unsaturated active metal sites and shorter diffusion paths, offer superior electrochemical performance. Additionally, by combining pristine 2D MOFs with other materials, hybrid 2D MOF materials can be created. These hybrids, with their enhanced stability and conductivity, can be directly utilized as active materials in lithium batteries. In the present review, we categorize 2D MOF-based materials into three distinct groups: pristine 2D MOFs, 2D MOF-derived materials, and 2D MOF hybrid materials. The synthesis methods for each group, along with their specific applications as electrode materials in lithium-ion batteries, are discussed in detail. This comprehensive review provides insights into the potential of 2D MOFs while highlighting the opportunities and challenges that are present in this evolving field. Keywords Li-ion batteries 2D materials 2D metal-organic frameworks Energy storage Synthesis 1 Introduction In the past decade, a variety of environmental issues and energy crises have arisen, prompting a concerted effort to develop electrochemical energy storage technologies as a potential solution to address these global challenges. With the promise of providing sustainable and efficient energy solutions, these technologies including batteries, fuel cells, and supercapacitors have emerged as the focal point of energy research [1–4]. Li-ion batteries (LIBs), a rapidly expanding category of secondary batteries, have become indispensable in a diverse array of technological applications owing to their high energy density, wide operating voltage window, low self-discharge rate, acceptable cycle life, and cost-effectiveness [5–7]. Among the applications driving advancements in LIB technologies, the automotive industry has undergone a revolution with the introduction of electric vehicles highly reliant on lithium-based batteries [8]. These batteries offer not only high storage capacity but also advantages in cycle life and charge/discharge C-rate. However, the development of this technology has faced challenges in utilizing appropriate electrode materials. Current anode and cathode materials have exhibited deficiencies in various aspects, including limited multiplying capacity, volume expansion, dendrite growth of lithium metal, compatibility at the separator interface, and instability of the cathode interface, that impede the further development of LIBs [9–11]. To address these challenges, the exploration of novel materials that mitigate these shortcomings is crucial for advancing high-performance LIBs. Introducing novel structures and chemical compositions with suitable physical and electrochemical properties holds the potential to enhance storage capacity and stability. In response to these demands, porous advanced materials have recently caught remarkable attention for energy storage applications [12–14]. Among these porous materials, metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have appeared as candidates with bright futures. MOFs are organic/inorganic hybrid materials constructed through the coordination of metal ions or clusters with organic linkers. Beyond their applications in different fields such as drug delivery [15], gas storage and separation [16], and catalysis [17], MOFs have also made significant progress in energy storage applications in recent years [18–20]. The unique structural properties of MOFs, including large internal surface area, controllable and diverse structures, tunable chemical components, interfacial charge transport, synthesis versatility, flexible molecular skeletons, and tailor-made induced functionalities, have positioned them as a novel electrode material for LIBs [21–29]. The highly porous structure of MOFs, resulting from the highly ordered adjustment of building units with open channels, facilitates the abundance of active metal sites, ensuring efficient lithium-ion storage. Moreover, the direct contact of electrolyte through rapid diffusion into the pores promotes the insertion and detachment of Li+ [12] while π–d-conjugated coordination between organic ligands and metal ions provides powerful electron delocalization throughout the whole structure, improving their electron storage properties through being reduced by the intercalated lithium ions [6,29]. Despite their structural advantages, early-investigated MOF structures have some problems such as negligible electrical conductivity, low tap density, and irreversible structural damage during charge/discharge processes, posing critical disadvantages for energy storage applications [30–32]. These shortcomings have prompted the introduction of new MOF structures with enhanced ion-diffusion characteristics and larger specific surface area. To this end, two-dimensional (2D) structures of MOFs have been proposed, offering much higher active sites, higher surface-to-volume ratio, and short transport distances for ions, thus demonstrating great potential as electrode materials in LIBs [33–36]. Facilitated electron transport through bond conduction (in-plane π–d conjugation) and spatial conduction (out-of-plane π–π conjugation) [37], along with abundant storage sites for lithium ions, enhances the electron transfer capability and inhibits lithium dendrite growth in 2D MOFs, making them specifically suitable for application in lithium-ion batteries [38]. In addition to the advantages introduced by pristine 2D MOFs, they can also serve as ideal precursors to form 2D MOF-derived materials, such as transition metal oxide nanosheets [39,40] and porous carbon nanosheets [41,42], which exhibit improved energy storage characteristics compared to pristine MOF structures. Furthermore, pristine 2D MOFs can be coupled with other nanomaterials, such as graphene [43], metallic and multi-metallic alloy nanoparticles [44], polyoxometalates (POMs) [45], polymers [46], and other 2D materials like MXenes [47,48], to form 2D MOF hybrids, leading to the combined benefits of both the hybridized components along with the base metal-organic framework material. In this review, we present a comprehensive overview of the recent progress and prospects of 2D MOF-based materials, encompassing pristine 2D MOFs, 2D MOF-derived materials, and 2D MOF composites/hybrids for use in LIBs. We begin by introducing the basic concepts and principles of 2D MOFs synthesis and preparation methods along with theoretical models. Then, we discuss the main strategies for fabricating Li-ion devices based on 2D MOFs and their respective performance. Finally, we provide an outlook on the current challenges associated with using 2D MOFs as active materials of choice in Li-ion batteries, along with suggesting possible directions for future research. 2 Why going 2D? Drawing inspiration from conventional 2D materials, the concept of designed two-dimensional structures of 2D MOFs has been proposed to harness the benefits of both traditional MOFs and the inherent properties of 2D structures [49–51]. Similar to layered materials such as graphene and transition metal dichalcogenides, when MOFs are exfoliated into nanosheets using the top-down approach or fabricated through the direct assembly of metal ions and organic linkers by coordination chemistry to create 2D sheets, their properties can be remarkably enhanced [52]. Compared to routine 2D materials, such enhancement in properties or the emergence of new properties is even more pronounced in case of MOFs, at least in theory [51,53–55]. This is due to the rich host-guest chemistry and the higher level of control that can be exercised by the combination of tunable organic ligands and functional metal ions with specific directionality offering a much richer playground for synthesizing tailor-made 2D MOFs for specific applications [56]. Furthermore, the self-assembly characteristics of 2D MOFs, akin to graphene oxide and other 2D materials liquid crystalline dispersions [57–62], can result in unique viscoelastic properties. These properties form the foundation for developing fabrication protocols for these 2D soft materials using various solution processing techniques [59,63–66]. However, despite the diversity and tunability that 2D MOFs can offer, positioning them as a category of technologically important 2D materials, these materials are largely neglected. Even at their most basic level, such enhanced properties can offer significant advantages for applications in electrochemical energy storage and conversion (Fig. 1 ). For example, the shorter diffusion paths in 2D MOFs can lead to a higher rate of charge transfer, reduced internal resistance, and significantly improved electrochemical activity. Furthermore, the hexagonal 2D lattices of electrically conductive 2D MOFs resemble graphite and other 2D materials stacked via van der Waals forces [67]. All the while, they maintain the highly ordered periodic porosity and large internal surface area that are characteristic of MOFs. With that in mind, we give a concise yet thorough overview of design strategies for the preparation of 2D MOFs. We emphasize that our primary focus has been on the preparation techniques commonly employed in Li-ion battery electrodes. 3 Design strategies for the preparation of pristine 2D MOFs 3.1 Addressing the complexities in the application of standard nomenclature 2D MOF structures can be systematically categorized by their topological motifs into 36 known computationally or experimentally distinct verified topologies [49,68]. These structures are recognized as 2-periodic coordination networks, which describe the systematic arrangement and interconnection of nodes (metal ions) and edges (organic linkers) within a two-dimensional matrix. In a 2-periodic coordination network, the nodes and edges create a repeating pattern in two dimensions, forming layers or sheets. The specific topology is characterized by the types of nodes and edges and how they are connected. During the development of an expert system for crystal design, grounded on the topology of 2-periodic coordination networks, it was discovered that the square lattice structure also referred to as ‘sql’, makes up about half of all known structures, out of more than 7000 structures represented in a standard representation [69]. Meanwhile, the honeycomb structure represents roughly one-fifth of all identified structures. Despite its inherent complexity, the potential to create an expert system capable of predicting both local and global topologies of periodic coordination networks present a fascinating yet underutilized approach. These complexities include the inherent complexities in topological descriptions, such as the loss of coordination geometry of metal ions or the interchangeability of square planar structures with octahedral or tetrahedral structural motifs, make the use of this topological nomenclature for a standardized expert system a notably challenging task, despite its informative and useful nature [70]. As such, in this review paper, our primary focus is not on the nomenclature of 2D MOFs, but rather on the principal synthesis and preparation methods. For a more comprehensive understanding of these structural motifs, we direct readers to several outstanding references that explain the structural motifs in detail [49,71,72]. The synthesis and preparation design strategies for pristine 2D MOF structures can be systematically executed through various methods. In literature, these methods can be broadly divided into two main categories: top-down and bottom-up approaches [33–35,49,73,74]. Fig. 2 illustrates the different design strategies typically used for the synthesis of 2D MOF-based materials. 3.2 Design strategies for the preparation of pristine 2D MOFs: Bottom-up approaches 3.2.1 Bottom-up approaches: Modulator-assisted techniques One of the key factors that makes 2D MOFs attractive for lithium-ion batteries is their capability to achieve precisely controllable morphologies and pore sizes through suitable synthesis methods. Materials featuring both micropores and mesopores, as found in two-dimensional structures of MOFs, are particularly advantageous because they facilitate the simultaneous diffusion and trapping of lithium ions. This dual-pore structure enhances the performance of 2D MOFs, making them highly desirable for battery applications [75]. Among the various methods available for the tailor-made synthesis of 2D MOFs, modulator-assisted techniques offer the most versatility. Modulators help control MOF crystallization beyond what the synthesis method alone can achieve. This technique employs modulators, such as monocarboxylic acids or amines, to regulate the coordination between metal ions and organic linkers during the synthesis of 2D MOFs. Therefore, by influencing the kinetics of crystal growth, modulators facilitate the formation of 2D structures [74]. However, we will not explore this approach in depth. Instead, we will provide a broad overview of its benefits, as its application in the design and regulation of 2D MOF structures for use in Li-ion batteries is somewhat limited. They can generate a wide array of unique structural types by creating different entanglements. Such an entangled system, comprising of either different or similar motifs that are interwoven or interlocked, is typically characterized as an extended periodic arrangement of structural motifs. These extended periodic arrays encompass four different structural arrangements: (i) interpenetration, (ii) polycatenation, (iii) polyrotaxane, and (iv) interdigitation. Entanglements of MOFs with flexible structures can be related to either interpenetration or polycatenation [76–78]. Although closely related, these two concepts are distinct from each other. In the case of interpenetration, a handful of individual motifs, which possess identical topological characteristics in either two or three-dimensional networks, are engaged. Each motif intertwines with others to form an infinitely expansive array within the same dimensions. Conversely, polycatenation involves a defined or boundless array of individual motifs of the same or different types (0D, 1D, or 2D with closed circuits). These motifs are interlaced, resulting in a structure of higher dimensionality. Polycatenated structures are most commonly observed in 1D to 2D transformations. Such transformations can occur by interweaving 1D chains into 2D structures, resulting in a unique supramolecular organization of the chains (Fig. 3 a). This can lead to the formation of warp-and-woof 2D sheets or fence (chicken) wiring of 1D chains (Fig. 3b) [79–81]. Furthermore, parallel or inclined polycatenation of 1D chains, as reported by Blake, can also result in the construction of 2D MOF motifs (Fig. 3c) [82]. An array of 2D MOFs has demonstrated the phenomenon where identical 2D nets intertwine in parallel to each other, contributing to the formation of a comprehensive 2D interpenetrated structure (Fig. 3d) [83]. It should be noted that the primary requirement for this structural formation is the corrugation of 2D sheets. In addition, Borromean links with three nets is another intriguing method of 2D to 2D interpenetration (Fig. 3e and f) [84]. This leads to the intertwining of two distinct nets when a third network is introduced. While such structures demonstrate great versatility, they have been seldom used in energy storage applications because of the complex structural characterization and the deep understanding of the structure required. Deciphering their inherent properties even in the case of 3D structures poses is a challenge due to the diminutive size of their crystals or their insufficient quality for crystal structure analysis [67]. However, despite being largely unexplored, we emphasize the immense versatility of these approaches, making them an unparalleled platform for the design of structures for various applications on demand. 3.2.2 Bottom-up approaches: Interfacial growth methods One of the bottom-up approach used for the synthesis of pristine 2D MOFs is interfacial growth, wherein the formation of nanosheets typically occurs at the two-dimensional space (interface) between two types of solvents according to a diffusion-mediated process [87]. Since the ligand and the metal ions used are bonded together in a two-dimensional space, a 2D composition is expected to be obtained. In this process, the crystal growth kinetics and subsequently the thickness of synthesized 2D MOFs are affected by factors such as temperature. Creating MOF structures with a high density of accessible active sites is a crucial factor that makes metal-organic framework materials attractive candidates for energy storage applications. The interfacial method offers a unique approach to designing such structures by introducing unsaturated coordinated metal sites (UCMSs) through controlled molar ratios of precursors used in the synthesis of the desired structure. This strategic design enables the creation of a high-density active site structure, essential for efficient energy storage and release in MOF-based batteries [33,88]. Although this method offers advantages in preparing large-area, ultrathin MOFs with high active sites, using this method for large-scale synthesis entails significant challenges due to the limited interface area [89]. Various pristine structures have been synthesized using this approach, such as hierarchical-pore MOFs (H-MOFs) [90], ultrathin porphyrin-hybridized bis(dipyrrinato)zinc(II) complex nanosheets [91], cobalt dithiolene framework [92], and Ag3BHT2 and Au3BHT2 [93]. For example, Wang et al. synthesized 2D Ni MOF nanosheets at the liquid/liquid interface through the coordination interaction between 1,4-BDC ligands dispersed in a mixture solution of dimethylacetamide (DMAC) and chloroform (CHCl3) and a nickel (II) acetate tetrahydrate aqueous solution (Fig. 4 a) [94]. A light-green product was formed between the interface of aqueous and organic phases by adding metallic aqueous solution into the organic solution (Fig. 4b). The resulting highly conductive 2D MOF products displayed 2D parallelogram-like features with lateral dimensions of approximately 200–450 nm (Fig. 4c) which can deliver excellent performance in electrochemical energy storage. 3.2.3 Bottom-up approaches: Hydro-solvothermal methods Hydro-solvothermal approaches represent one of the primary synthesis routes for forming pristine 2D MOFs, wherein the sheets are formed via coordination interactions of metal ions and organic linkers as building blocks. As this method can be employed for the growth of bulk structures, planar growth and the formation of 2D structures need precise, fully controlled synthesis conditions for structural confinement. The hydro-solvothermal method has been a conventional and scalable strategy for synthesizing MOF crystals over the last two decades [49,95–97] and has recently been demonstrated as an established method for preparing 2D MOF materials. Examples include cupric-TPA nanosheets [98], Zr/Hf MOF nanosheets [99], Ni-M-MOF (M = Fe, Al, Co, Mn, Zn, and Cd) nanosheets [100], ultrathin MF-ZrBTB [101], Cu-TCPP [102], 2D Cu-THQ [103], Ni-BHC [104], and 2D CoBDC [105]. Conventionally, this synthesis approach utilizes a mixed solution of metal salt and organic ligand that react at a certain temperature and pressure. Adjusting parameters such as temperature, pressure, solvent composition, and reaction time during solvothermal synthesis allows for tuning the morphology, porosity, and surface area of the resulting 2D MOFs [106]. By carefully controlling these synthesis parameters, the solvothermal method can produce 2D MOFs with tailored properties, including high surface area, porosity, conductivity, and structural stability. These optimized characteristics make them promising candidates for high-performance lithium-ion battery electrodes. For instance, Jiang et al. employed a simple solvothermal strategy for the preparation of a redox-active 2D Cu-THQ metal-organic framework using THQ as the key ligand with redox activity and copper ions, which can enhance the number of redox-active sites and generate nanopores resulting in honeycomb layered structures with ∼ 1.1 nm hexagonal pores (Fig. 5 ) [103]. The resulting MOF showed enhanced porosity while exhibiting inherent redox activity making it suitable for lithium storage applications. The preferential directional growth in the this process can be influenced by the choice of surfactants and reaction temperature [107], and the morphology, size, and crystalline structure of the synthesized 2D MOFs in this study, affected by the type and percentage of solvents participating in the reaction [108,109]. 3.3 Design strategies for the preparation of pristine 2D MOFs: Top-down approaches In contrast to bottom-up approaches, top-down methods have been widely utilized to create pristine 2D MOFs. This is primarily due to the simplicity of the synthesis routes, although it often comes at the cost of quality and versatility. Employing various top-down approaches, as referenced in Fig. 2, including diverse exfoliation techniques, can yield 2D MOF nanosheets that span several micrometers in lateral dimension. However, one aspect that remains largely unexplored is the examination of the existence of liquid crystal structures in different solvents, given the presence of multifunctional groups on the surface of 2D MOFs and their large lateral sizes. This also includes the subsequent liquid crystal solution processing techniques to transform these intriguing 2D sheets into practical 3D architectures, similar to graphene oxide liquid crystals. We emphasize that if this approach is successful, it could unlock new opportunities for processing 2D MOFs for different applications, such as catalysis, sensing, separation, and energy storage (both electrochemical and hydrogen storage) [110,111]. Compared to bulk MOFs, which primarily contain active sites within their bulk, 2D nanosheets feature a vast number of active sites on their surface contributing to an increased reactivity. However, the crucial technological aspect that could lead to the widespread adoption of these materials is our ability to transform these two-dimensional structures into practical 3D forms. This must be done while maintaining the minimum spacing necessary to preserve their 2D activity, using solution processing techniques. This can be accomplished by mapping the viscoelastic behavior of their dispersions into various solution processing methods [60,63,64,66]. The key enabling factor in this context is the ability to achieve dispersible 2D MOFs in suitable dispersing agents, or solvents, which are typically polar in nature. It is worth noting that apart from water, only a handful of solvents can support amphiphilic self-organization [57–59]. These consist of a limited selection of multifunctional alcohols, amides, and a broad spectrum of protic ionic liquids (PILs) [112,113]. In the case of PILs, where the solvent itself is an ion, the screening of surface charge yields in a partial electrostatic contribution [114,115]. This contrasts with organic solvents and water, where electrostatic charges significantly influence the free energy associated with ordering. In the scenario of probable liquid crystal dispersions of 2D MOFs, the solvent trapped between the charged MOF sheets assumes a more structured adjustment to create a slow balance between the steric and repulsive forces. In this context, 2D MOFs can be viewed as self-assembling materials. Their intricate chemistry facilitates supramolecular interactions, which include electrostatic repulsion among adjacent sheets and hydrogen bonding with solvent molecules. [116]. These interactions compensate for the reduction in rotational entropy observed during self-assembly. In the context of organic solvents, this self-assembly is regulated by a delicate equilibrium between the ability to establish numerous hydrogen bonds and the existence of electrostatic charges, as indicated by the Gordon parameter [57]. However, considering the significantly higher reactivity of metal active sites in 2D MOFs, we envisage that solvents like THF, which are widely used for the protection and self-assembly of metallic nanoparticles such as magnesium [117] or boron [118], could be the most suitable solvents for achieving liquid crystal dispersions. Top-down approaches: Exfoliation methods As a widely-used top-down synthesis strategy, exfoliation techniques have been employed for 2D MOF preparation from bulk layered counterparts by breaking interlayer interactions such as π–π interaction of organic ligands construction of aromatic rings of, van der Waals force, and/or hydrogen bonding [33,34,49,73]. This process can be achieved through either physical or chemical exfoliation routes. In physical methods, layer separation occurs through the intervention of external physical forces. Wet ball milling [119,120], ultrasonication [121–123], and shaking [124] are the main preparation techniques for 2D MOF materials by physical exfoliation. Ball mill exfoliation of 2D MOFs is typically conducted in a wet environment incorporating two solvents. During this process, interlayer interaction forces weaken through ball penetration into interlayer spaces. One solvent penetrates into the galleries of the layered MOF, while the other helps stabilize the structure of the 2D MOF sheets akin to a surfactant [125,126]. Ball milling offers significant advantages over other solution-based methods for synthesizing 2D MOFs, including dramatically reduced reaction times and the ability to produce large quantities of MOFs in a single batch. These benefits greatly enhance the scalability and potential for industrial applications of MOF synthesis [127]. Despite the simplicity and efficiency of this strategy, limited crystallinity, heterogeneities of the product, and moderate porosity have restricted its use in the synthesis of 2D MOFs and employing them as electrode materials in lithium ion batteries [126]. Sonication exfoliation presents another facile and easily scalable 2D MOF preparation route, utilizing ultrasonic waves to break the interlayer bonding [126,128–130]. By controlling ultrasonic power, energy, and solvent selection, 2D MOF sheets with desired characteristics such as thickness, lateral size, and concentration can be synthesized, enabling customization for specific battery applications [131]. However, low yield and uncontrollable morphology due to nanosheet breakage and re-stacking problems are notable issues associated with this strategy [73]. Combining ball milling and sonication methods has remediated these shortcomings. As an example, highly crystalline MOF nanosheets (pristine Zn2(bim)4) have been prepared using a combined ball mill/sonication exfoliation method in the presence of methanol and propanol [132]. This resulted in a flake-like morphology (Fig. 6 a) and a grid-like structure (Fig. 6b and c). It is hypothesized that the penetration of small methanol molecules into the galleries of the layered Zn2(bim)4, facilitated by wet ball-milling, and propanol with hydrophobic alkane tails absorbing on the MOF sheets, resulted in stabilizing the exfoliated nanosheets. The lack of controllability in the resulting structures obtained through physical exfoliation processes renders them unsuitable for layer separation of certain stable MOF structures, such as pillar-layer type MOFs. Chemical exfoliation offers a solution in these cases [133–136]. During the chemical exfoliation process, due to the intercalation of ligands or solvent molecules into the interlayer spaces, chemical bonds selectively break, resulting in the delamination of MOF structures and the formation of ultrathin MOF sheets [135]. Additionally, exfoliation can be achieved through electrochemical processes, wherein external electrical forces aid in breaking the strong coordination bonds such as that present in pillared-layer type MOFs. About pillared-layer MOFs, the pillar ligand with selective oxidation ability in the bulk MOF structure can be removed via an electrochemical reaction, resulting in the formation of 2D MOF nanosheets. For instance, Huang et al. utilized a chemical/electrochemical exfoliation method for the preparation of a pillared-layer three-dimensional MOF by selectively removing its pillars, resulting in the preparation of 2D Cobalt nanosheets (2D-Co-NS) (Fig. 6d) with wrinkled morphologies and ultrathin sheets (with a thickness of approximately 2 nm) (Fig. 6e and f) [134]. Despite the advantages, such as simplicity and low cost of preparation, brought by the exfoliation strategy, the aforementioned shortcomings in each technique, along with their incapability to exfoliate MOF structures with large interlayer distances and strong coordination bonds, pose significant limitations [137,138]. On the other hand, the chemical exfoliation process can introduce structural defects into two-dimensional MOF nanosheets, including vacancies, dislocations, and edge defects. These defects can significantly alter the electronic properties and electrochemical performance of the material, potentially influencing its overall performance in lithium-ion batteries [36]. Besides, challenges in obtaining uniform thickness and morphologies [73] further restrict the applicability of exfoliation techniques in the fabrication of energy storage devices. 4 Design strategies for the preparation of 2D MOF-derived materials Pristine 2D MOFs serve as promising precursors for synthesizing various 2D MOF-derived materials, including porous carbon nanosheets [41,139], transition metal oxide nanosheets [140], metal compounds [141], and their composites [142]. 2D MOF-derived materials can inherit the internal structure of the pristine 2D MOF [143], resulting in more favorable properties and desirable structures compared to their pristine counterparts. These enhancements can significantly impact mass/electron transport and the exposure of active sites [144–146]. Numerous efforts have been dedicated to converting pristine 2D MOFs into 2D MOF-derived materials, and the following is a summary of the preparation methods for these derivatives. Template-combined thermal treatment approach In recent years, the layered and two-dimensional structure of 2D MOFs has been utilized as a template for synthesizing various material groups. The presence of metallic ions and ligands in the MOF structure can facilitate the synthesis process by preparing initial components, while its planar structure aids in the formation of nanosheets. An example of materials prepared by this method is Transition Metal Oxides (TMOs). As a representative, Co3O4 nanosheets, widely used in various energy applications [143,147–150], can be easily prepared through a template-combined thermal treatment approach by utilizing cobalt-based 2D MOFs. Wei et al. employed a self-template strategy to prepare ultrathin Co3O4 from 2D ZIF-67, which was pre-synthesized from Co2+ and 2-MeIM in an annealing process (Fig. 7 a) [151]. The resulting mesoporous Co3O4 nano-meshes maintain the structure of the 2D MOF precursor and exhibit a uniform porous feature (Fig. 7b, c). In another study, Zheng et al. prepared napoleons-like Co3O4 (NL-Co3O4) structures from 2D layered Co-MOF at a pyrolysis temperature of 400 °C (Fig. 7d) [143]. The layered, porous structure in the synthesized NL-Co3O4 is inherited from the Co-MOF template skeleton and derived through the decomposition of the Co-MOF organic ligands into gas molecules, forming monolayer thickness of approximately 70 nm. Besides TMO materials, a subclass of these materials, mixed transition metal oxides (MTMOs) or bimetallic TMO hybrids, can also be formed from 2D MOF precursors. These materials overcome volume expansion and poor electrical conductivity problems associated with using TMOs in electrochemical reactions. For instance, zinc manganese oxide (ZMO) nanosheets, a potential material for energy storage applications, have been synthesized using 2D Zn-Mn-MOF nanosheets [152]. By using PVP as a soft template, lamellar micelles for the formation of 2D Zn-Mn-MOF are realized in the first step. Further thermal treatment resulted in ZMO nanosheets with large lateral dimensions and with the same morphology of pristine precursor (Fig. 7e). In another strategy, bimetallic 2D MOFs were used as precursors to produce bimetallic 2D MOF-derived materials with enhanced electrochemical performance. Fang et al. successfully designed hybrid bimetallic TMOs (Co3O4/ZnO) from CoZn-MOFs through a simple heat treatment process (Fig. 7f) [153]. The obtained Co3O4/ZnO consisted of several small ultrathin wafers connected with each other, resulting in a sheet structure. Because of the electrochemical synergistic effects between Co3O4 and ZnO, the synthesized nanosheets exhibited good performance as active materials in lithium batteries. It is also suggested that the thickness of TMO sheets could be adjusted to the thickness of 2D MOF sheets. Porous carbon structures are among the materials that can be effectively prepared using 2D MOFs with controlled thickness and pore structure as templates. Recently, various types of 2D MOFs have been successfully utilized for synthesizing derived porous carbon nanosheets, including ZIF-8 nanosheets [154,155], 2D Zn(bim) MOFs [156], and Zn/Fe-MOFs [42], via a self-template combined thermal treatment method. For instance, Zhao et al. prepared ultrathin carbon nanosheets (UT-CNSs) with thicknesses ranging from 2.5 to 0.8 nm using previously synthesized ultrathin Zn(bim)(OAc) MOFs (Fig. 8 a), which were initially prepared via a low-cost bottom-up synthesis [156]. They obtained N-doped UT-CNSs with a porous structure and high-volume pore size through the carbonization of the as-synthesized MOF nanosheets (Fig. 8b–e). Thermal treatment can improve the stability and electrochemical performance of MOF-derived materials by removing residual solvents, enhancing crystallinity, and optimizing the structure for better lithium-ion storage and cycling stability. It can also lead to the formation of MOF-derived materials with increased specific surface area, which enhances the electrode-electrolyte interface and improves lithium-ion diffusion kinetics in batteries. Furthermore, thermal treatment methods can increase the porosity of MOF-derived materials, providing more active sites for lithium-ion storage and facilitating efficient ion transport within the electrode material, thereby improving battery performance [143]. However, High-temperature thermal treatment can lead to the degradation or collapse of the 2D MOF structure, reducing the specific surface area and porosity that are crucial for lithium-ion storage. Elevated temperatures may cause the loss or decomposition of organic linkers in 2D MOFs, altering the original composition and potentially reducing the redox-active sites for lithium-ion storage [151]. Additionally, during thermal treatment, the 2D MOF nanosheets may agglomerate, leading to a decrease in specific surface area and reduced accessibility of active sites [157]. 5 2D MOF composite material preparation methods In the last decade, the fabrication of MOF composites with other materials has made significant advances, largely due to the potential that hybrid structures offer across a broad spectrum of applications. Owing to their porous and flexible structure, pristine 2D MOFs can integrate seamlessly with a variety type of nanomaterials, such as nanoparticles [158], polyoxometalates [159,160], carbon nanotubes [161], and other 2D materials [162,163]. This results in 2D MOF-based composite materials that exhibit novel, enhanced properties and performance. The methods for fabricating 2D MOF composites generally fall into two categories: in situ strategies and hybrid methods, both of which will be discussed in detail. 5.1 2D MOF composite material preparation methods: In situ strategy 5.1.1 In situ intercalation of 2D MOFs In this approach, the composite material is synthesized concurrently with the 2D MOF. As the organic linkers and metal ions coalesce, the target nanomaterial is intercalated, leading to the composite structures. The 2D MOFs proliferate around these intercalated nanomaterials, which serve as a scaffold for MOF crystal growth and inhibit the agglomeration of the nascent 2D MOFs. Integrating this approach not only fine-tunes the layer thickness of the 2D MOF but also enhances charge transfer across the hybrid nanostructure. The MOF hybrids, featuring ultrathin nanosheets, are enriched with numerous electroactive sites, significantly elevating their electrochemical efficiency [164]. A notable instance of this method is the fabrication of a 2D hybrid material comprising MOF nanosheets and ultra-thin carboxylated carbon nanotubes (C-CNTs), as devised by Ran et al., employing an in-situ intercalation strategy [164]. In this study, Ni-MOF/C-CNTs were synthesized via a solvothermal reaction from a solution containing C-CNTs dispersed in DMF, H3BTC, and Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (Fig. 9 a). In this manner, ultrathin MOF nanosheets with interpenetrated functional CNTs were formed. SEM and TEM analysis demonstrate the effective role of the CNT in generating a 2D sheet-like composite of Ni-MOF (Fig. 9b–e). The authors observed that the intercalated CNT prevented the aggregation of Ni-MOF layers which can be observed in SEM images of pure and CNT-intercalated structures presented in Fig. 9(b and c). TEM image of Ni-MOF/C-CNTs with a sheet thickness of 3–4 nm (Fig. 9e), demonstrates thinner structures in contrast to that of pure Ni-MOF (Fig. 9d). 5.1.2 In situ growth of 2D MOFs in the surface The preparation of 2D MOF composites can also involve growing 2D MOFs on the surface of other nanomaterials. Graphene, a well-known 2D nanostructure of carbon atoms, has been extensively utilized in different applications such as energy storage, sensors, and gas storage due to its desirable properties [165]. Integrating MOFs with graphene results in a composite with enhanced properties based on each component. One strategy for preparing MOF/graphene composite materials involves growing a 2D MOF on the graphene surface. Liu et al. utilized graphene as the substrate for growing ultrathin MOF nanosheets (UMOFNs) with controllable growth orientations [166]. In this approach, the 2-MeIM ligands and metal ions were added to a dispersed solution of GO, resulting in the attachment of MOF ligands to the GO surface through interaction between N atoms in MOF ligands and O atoms in GO. This led to the formation of UMOFNs@GO-F composite with a foam-like hierarchical structure via a heterogeneous nucleation pathway (Fig. 10 ). Nanoparticles can be used as desirable surfaces for the in-situ growth of 2D MOFs. In this approach, solutions of organic linkers and metal ions are added to dispersed nanoparticle solutions, facilitating coordination interactions between the metallic ions and the organic linkers of the MOF around the nanoparticles resulted in the formation of a MOF network surrounding the nanoparticles. Nazir et al. illustrated the in-situ growth of 2D MOF around Si nanoparticles (SiNPs) by adding solutions containing (Cu(SO4) + NH4OH) and (HATP + 6HCl) to the dispersed solution of Si nanoparticles (Fig. 11 a) [167]. Through in-situ growth of Cu3(HITP)2 as a 2D MOF on the SiNPs surface at room temperature, the Si nanoparticles were encapsulated with the surrounding 2D MOFs (Fig. 11b), leading to the formation of Si@Cu3(HITP)2 composites with a porous structure (Fig. 11c–e). Optimizing the properties of pristine 2D MOFs can be achieved by preparing composites with other 2D materials possessing unique properties, such as MXenes [168–170], graphitic carbon nitride (g-C3N4) [171,172], layered double hydroxides [173,174], and black phosphorus (BP). The incorporation of these materials into composite forms generates synergistic effects, enhancing their capabilities in various applications. BP, as a new class of layered semiconductors, has garnered tremendous attention in recent years, leading to the investigation of numerous BP-based composite materials across various applications [175]. Jin et al. prepared a hybrid material (BP/NiCo MOF) from a few-layer black phosphorus and NiCo MOF through an in-situ preparation method [176]. In this synthesis process, benzenedicarboxylic acid was added to a dispersed solution of BP nanosheets. After sonication of the obtained solution, the carboxylate groups in BDC ligands bonded to BP layers. By adding metal ions to this solution, BDC ligands chelated with metal ions, and in the end the 2D- few layer hybrid material was formed via growing 2D NiCo MOF on the BP surface (BP/NiCo) with sheet-like morphology (Fig. 12 a, b). MXenes represent another class of 2D materials with the possibility to raise the properties of 2D MOFs through composite formation. MXenes can serve as a support for coating 2D MOFs onto their surface via interdiffusion reactions. This reaction occurs between interdiffused metal ions and organic ligands in a mixed solvent and can be utilized for in-situ synthesis of 2D MOFs on other material surfaces such as MXenes. Due to the hydrophilic nature of MXene nanosheets' surfaces, the aggregation of MOF layers can be prevented. Very presently, the heterostructure of MXene nanosheets and Ni-ferrocene dicarboxylic MOF (NF-MOF) was obtained (NF-MOF@MXene) through mixing Ni2+ ions and 1,1-dicarboxyferrocene ligands precursors, with MXene sheets to allow in-situ growth of Ni-based MOF on Ti3C2T x MXene nanosheets (Fig. 12c) [47]. Layered double hydroxides (LDHs) represent another class of 2D materials with unique physical, chemical, and electronic properties that have the potential to form hybrid materials with 2D MOFs [177,178]. The nucleation and growth of 2D MOF structures on LDH surfaces can be achieved through the interconnected pores of LDH nanoplatelets, which serve as a reactor. Following this strategy, Xu and his coworkers designed a hybrid material composed of 2D MOF and ternary LDH hierarchical structure [174]. They utilized 3D hierarchical ZIF-67/CoNiAl-LDH/NF which was prepared with in-situ growing of 2D zeolitic imidazolate framework-67 (ZIF-67) and CoNiAl ternary layered double hydroxide (CoNiAl-LDH) nanoplatelets on the surface of conductive 3D nickel foam (NF) skeleton. Initially, vertically aligned CoNiAl-LDH nanoplatelets were grown on the surface of the conductive 3D nickel foam skeleton through a hydrothermal method, followed by the uniform deposition of rhombic dodecahedral ZIF-67 nanocrystals on the surface of interconnected LDH nanoplatelets. In this process, nanosheet arrays of 2D ZIF-67 were grown onto the surface of LDH nanoplatelets via an in-situ crystallization-dissolution recrystallization procedure from Co(NO3)2·6H2O and 2MeIM as precursors, resulting in a 2D MOF hybrid material (ZIF-67/CoNiAl-LDH/NF) with a sheet-like structure and strong-coupled interfaces (Fig. 12d). 5.1.3 Spray technique Spray techniques have emerged as an ideal approach for preparing materials with excellent mechanical properties and have recently been employed for the formation of nanoporous MOF composites [179]. This approach allows for the formation of composites with materials exhibiting outstanding mechanical properties, such as fibers, thereby promoting the mechanical stability of MOFs, which has been a significant concern in utilizing these materials [180,181]. In an attempt to prepare 2D MOF@fiber composites, Zhang et al. developed an in-situ growing strategy to prepare a hybrid material of MOF nanosheets (CuBDC) and carbon fiber (CF) under mild conditions [179]. In this process, the BDC ligand absorbs on the surface of carbon fibers in the initial stage, followed by spraying Cu ion solution, resulting in the formation of MOF nanosheets through coordination with the ligand. Consequently, the surface of the carbon fiber is homogeneously and densely covered by well-ordered growing nanosheets (Fig. 13 a). The SEM and XRD pattern of CuBDC@CF show the hybrid structure preparation and high crystallinity of CuBDC located on the CFs, respectively (Fig. 13b–d). 5.2 2D MOF composite material preparation methods: Hybrid methods Another approach to preparing 2D MOF hybrid materials involves the initial formation of 2D MOFs through the selection of suitable metal ions and ligands, followed by their combination with other nanomaterials. Depending on the type of precursors and the intended application of such hybrid materials, various methods can be considered for their preparation, as briefly discussed below. 5.2.1 Growing nanomaterials on MOF nanosheets 2D MOF nanocomposites can be attained through the rapid growth of various nanoparticles on the surface of 2D MOFs. In this method, the MOF structure is initially formed, and then the nanoparticles adhere to their surface to create a hybrid structure with the 2D MOFs. For example, Lu et al. reported the in-situ preparation of metal sulfide nanoparticles on 2D MOF nanosheets (Fig. 14 a) [182]. In their approach, a hybrid material of 2D MOF is formed via the direct sulfidation of 2D Cu-TCPP nanosheets, according to the reaction of metal ions in MOFs and sulfide anions from TAA as the sulfide source in the liquid phase. This results in the formation of single-crystalline CuS nanoparticles on the Cu-TCPP nanosheets, leading to the CuS/Cu-TCPP nanocomposite with a porous structure (Fig. 14b, c). 5.2.2 Intercalation of nanomaterials into 2D MOFs Intercalating nanomaterials between the layers of 2D MOFs is considered one of the effective methods for preparing 2D MOF nanocomposites. This process begins with the initial formation of 2D MOF materials, followed by the addition of nanomaterials and the establishment of an intercalation process. Importantly, inserting nanomaterials into MOFs not only enhances the properties of the MOFs but also benefits the nanoparticles themselves. This integration prevents the further growth of the nanoparticles, maintaining their effectiveness in various applications due to their nanometer size. Wang et al. successfully prepared a 2D MOF composite by incorporating multi-walled carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs) within ultrathin sheets of Cu-TCPP using an ultrasonic mixing method (Fig. 14d) [183]. The TEM images of resulting pristine MOF (Fig. 14e) and 2D Cu-TCPP/MWCNT composite film (Fig. 14f) exhibited a strong combination of MWCNTs and 2D MOF, suggesting interactions between the MOF ligands and MWCNTs. This synthesis method provides an easy and facile strategy for preparing composites based on two-dimensional MOF nanosheets. 5.2.3 Encapsulation combined exfoliation Another strategy for preparing MOF composites includes the encapsulation of nanomaterials inside MOF cavities. Many materials have been used for encapsulation within the cavities of MOFs, enhancing the efficiency and applicability of these materials. This technique can also be applied to prepare two-dimensional MOF composites. Conventionally, three-dimensional MOFs are initially synthesized, and nanomaterials are encapsulated inside the cavities. Subsequently, a further exfoliation process leads to MOF nanosheets containing encapsulated nanomaterials. The encapsulation combined with exfoliation method for synthesizing 2D MOF composites integrates the advantages of top-down exfoliation to fabricate functional composite materials. This innovative strategy allows for the rapid construction of composite nanosheets with large lateral dimensions and controlled thickness from 2D MOF precursors and guest molecules, achieving high yields [184]. Polyoxometalates (POMs) as a large class of inorganic polyanionic clusters with nanometer sizes, exhibiting functionality in different applications such as catalysis [185], magnetism [186], electronics [187], optics [188], and energy conversion [189]. Despite the versatile chemical, electrochemical, and structural properties of POMs [184], dissolution and partial degradation issues have limited their applications [189]. Encapsulation within porous solid matrices represents one strategy to overcome these disadvantages [184]. POMs have been successfully incorporated into MOFs to produce POM-based MOFs, combining the advantages of POMs (multi-electron redox process) and MOFs (high surface area and favorable pores). A vast number of MOFs and their derivatives have been utilized for the encapsulation of POMs [45,190–195]. However, a challenge with bulk MOF encapsulation processes is the potential blocking of many pores, leading to a loss of effectiveness [196]. This issue is addressed by converting the three-dimensional structure of MOFs encapsulated with POMs into two-dimensional MOF@POM composites. 2D MOF@POM composites have been successfully prepared by Xu et al. [197]. In their approach, POMs [PMo12O40] were encapsulated into a layered-structure Co-MOF [Co2(H2O)4(BTX)3], resulting in the formation of three-dimensional POM@Co-MOF. Further wet ball-milling and sonication-assisted top-down exfoliation delaminated the prepared POM@Co-MOF into ultrathin nanosheets (Fig. 14g) with the typical lamellar structure (Fig. 14h). 6 Assessing the impact of MOF synthesis strategies: Implications for LIB electrode performance The various synthesis methods for the preparation of two-dimensional MOF structures each offer unique benefits and drawbacks when considered for use as electrode materials in lithium-ion batteries. In synthesizing pristine 2D MOFs, bottom-up approaches provide greater control over the morphology and resulting structures. The size and thickness of the synthesized sheets along with the pore size and distribution can be precisely modulated through adjusting synthesis parameters in each approach. The proper choice of modulators as in the modulator-assisted synthesis, the solvents and reaction temperature in interfacial growth method and controlling temperature and pressure in hydro-solvothermal methods can result in mesoporous structures with high surface area, desirable for accommodating lithium ions in host electrode’s structure and facilitating interfacial charge transport. Achieving desirable morphologies in synthesis process is a hard task in top-down approaches which can be efficiently provided in bottom-up methods. Nevertheless, bottom-up approaches commonly suffer from low yield in final production and challenges in scalability. The limited interface in interfacial growth hinders formation of large-area sheets, the complexities in utilizing modulators in growth process impose hurdles to modulator-assisted synthesis and the energy budget issues constrains the large-scale productibility of hydro-solvothermal methods. To address these challenges, achieving 2D structures from bulky materials could be a solution. Exfoliation methods, including ball milling, ultrasonication, and chemical exfoliation, offer swift and energy-efficient production with high yields, though they come at the cost of reduced control over morphology. Despite the benefits provided by these techniques, the obtained products commonly suffer from structural damages, lack of thickness uniformity, size reduction and are contaminated with either ball milling compounds or solvents which dramatically influence their application in lithium-ion storage and cyclability of LIBs. The structural characteristics of 2D MOFs, such as high surface area and mesoporous structures, make them desirable templates for the growth of other 2D structures. MOF-derived nanosheets benefit from the tunability inherited from their precursor structures, affecting their conductivity, surface chemistry, and structural stability. However, derived nanostructures from metal organic frameworks can suffer from potential impurities due to ligand decomposition during thermal treatment, which unavoidably accompanies the synthesis process and alters the ion-storage performance of the resulting structures by reducing accessibility of active sites. Harnessing the remarkable features of MOFs in energy devices can also be obtained through 2D MOF composite structures. Forming composites through in-situ strategies preserves the structural characteristics of MOF compounds while enhancing electrochemical performance by incorporating other redox-active materials such as graphene, MXenes, and LDHs. On the other hand, hybrid strategies offer the introduction of nanomaterials into the MOF structures enhancing the overall energy storage performance of electrodes. However, integrating these nanomaterials into MOF structures, particularly through techniques like encapsulation, requires successful exfoliation of the 2D MOF precursor into nanosheets with the desired thickness and lateral dimensions suitable for battery applications. This challenge may necessitate optimization of exfoliation conditions. Balancing the need for exfoliation with the preservation of the structural integrity of the 2D MOF during encapsulation is crucial to ensure that the composite retains its desired properties and functionalities for specific applications. Nevertheless, deriving 3D structures from 2D materials preserves the features of high aspect ratio compounds while providing spatial galleries that facilitate lithium-ion accommodation and interfacial charge transport. 7 2D MOF-based materials for Li-ion batteries Among rechargeable batteries, lithium-ion batteries are at the forefront. These types of batteries consist of negative (anode) and positive (cathode) electrodes, a separator (which facilitates the transport of Li ions), and an electrolyte (which conducts Li-ions during charging and discharging). During the charging process, lithium ions move from the cathode electrode to the anode electrode, allowing energy to be stored in the lithium-ion batteries. During discharge, lithium ions migrate from the negative electrode back to the positive electrode, causing the LIBs to release the stored energy [24]. The ongoing exploration of advanced materials for being used in LIB structures especially as electrode materials, aims to achieve improved battery performance Fig. 15 delineates the characteristics of 2D MOF-based materials, rendering them appropriate for application as electrode materials. 7.1 2D MOF-based materials for LIBs: Cathode applications When considering cathode electrode materials for lithium-ion batteries, the choice is crucial as it directly affects energy density and cost. Common cathode materials include lithium cobalt oxide (LiCoO2), lithium manganese oxide (LiMn2O4), lithium iron phosphate (LiFePO4 or LFP), and lithium nickel manganese cobalt oxide (LiNiMnCoO2 or NMC). Although LiCoO2 offers high capacity and voltage, concerns over its cost, toxicity, and thermal instability have driven the search for alternative cathode materials with better performance and safety profiles [198]. One such alternative is the spinel cathode material, lithium manganese oxide (LiMn2O4). LiMn2O4 stands out as an ideal cathode material due to its abundant raw material resources, lower cost, heightened safety, and ease of preparation. However, challenges such as capacity fading and low conductivity hinder efficient charge transfer and overall battery performance when utilizing LiMn2O4 in lithium-ion batteries [199,200]. Another alternative is the olivine cathode material, lithium iron phosphate (LiFePO4). With a theoretical specific capacity of 170 mA h g−1, LiFePO4 offers good cycling performance and stability during charging and discharging. Its advantages include low cost, a good safety profile, and the absence of harmful elements. However, LiFePO4 suffers from low energy density and poor electrical conductivity, which negatively impact its electrochemical performance [201]. Nickel manganese cobalt (NMC) battery as a type of lithium-ion battery, combines nickel, manganese, and cobalt in its cathode composition. These cathode materials are widely utilized across a range of applications, including electric vehicles, personal electronic devices, and stationary electrochemical energy storage systems. While common anode and cathode materials have certain limitations, ongoing efforts focus on retrofitting these materials and developing novel alternatives to address these shortcomings [202]. Pristine 2D MOFs with a significant presence of Li+ storage sites have been directly utilized as electrode materials in lithium-ion batteries [176,203]. There are three primary reasons for employing pristine 2D MOFs as electrode materials in LIBs. First, 2D MOFs possess plentiful open micro/nano-sized pores, facilitating the storage of a sufficient number of lithium ions and leading to much higher lithium ion diffusion than 3D porous and non-porous materials [26]. Moreover, the organic ligands in the structure of 2D MOFs contain unsaturated bonds, which can open and re-bond during the electrochemical reaction, thereby conserving reversible energy and aiding in the energy storage process. An additional attribute that enhances the appeal of these structures is the reversible electrochemical conversion reaction of metal ion clusters within the 2D MOFs. This reaction not only promotes electron mobility but also acts as a source of reversible capacity for the electrode [204]. Recently, there has been exploration into the use of pristine MOFs with a 2D structure as cathode materials in lithium-ion batteries. Tian et al. studied the impact of porosity in the 2D structure on the performance of Li batteries [26]. They designed a porous, 2D square-grid structure of MOFs for implementation as cathode materials in LIBs. The authors discovered that the porous 2D MOF obtained exhibited a significantly higher lithium-ion diffusion coefficient (D Li) compared to the non-porous 1D MOF. Nagatomi et al. [205] and Gu et al. [206] investigated the impact of porosity and the redox activity of metal ions in Cu-based 2D MOF structures on the performance of lithium-ion batteries. They synthesized MOF nanosheets as cathode materials with notable electrochemical properties. The authors found this outstanding electrochemical performance in the open porous layered framework, which provides open tunnels for lithium ions, and the reversible redox of Cu2+/Cu+ in the electrode during the charging and discharging steps (Fig. 16 a). This led to high reversible discharge and charge capacity, as well as high columbic efficiency (Fig. 16b). In another study, Jiang et al. demonstrated the simultaneous effect of both metal ions and organic ligands on the remarkable redox activity during the charge/discharge processes [103]. They utilized the THQ linker to coordinate with copper ions, preparing a 2D honeycomb layered framework (Cu-THQ) as a cathode material in LIBs. The transformation of C = O bonds and C–O bonds in the ligand structure, along with the transformation of Cu(I) to Cu(II) (Fig. 17 a), resulted in a good reversible capacity (387 mA h g−1) and specific energy density (775 Wh kg−1) with desirable cycling stability (Fig. 17b). Wu et al. successfully synthesized an excellent cathode material, stable redox-active 2D MOFs (Cu-BHT) [207]. This study indicates that the BHT ligands in the structure of the prepared 2D MOF participate more in the redox reaction compared to the Cu(II) metal ions. The constant presence of copper atoms protects the backbone for electron/ion diffusion (Fig. 17c). An outstanding reversible capacity, cycle stabilities, and rate capability were observed for Cu-BHT during the electrochemical process (Fig. 17d, e). 7.2 2D MOF-based materials for Li-ion batteries: Anode applications The most widely used anode materials in lithium-ion batteries include carbon-based materials, silicon-based materials, and metal compound materials such as lithium-titanium oxide (LTO). Among these, carbon materials, including graphite, have gained significant attention due to their multistage structure, excellent conductivity, widespread availability, and relatively low cost. However, they possess a relatively low theoretical capacity (372 mA h g−1) and low voltage plateau [9,208,209]. Graphite anodes, the primary choice for lithium-ion batteries, typically exhibit a cycle life of around 300–500 cycles. In contrast, LTO based anodes have demonstrated striking ability to maintain their capacity and performance for over 2000 cycles, making them a more reliable and durable option for energy storage applications [210,211]. Silicon-based materials offer a significant increase in energy storage capacity compared to traditional anodes. With a theoretical capacity of 4200 mA h g−1, these materials have the potential to revolutionize the development of high-capacity energy storage systems [212–214]. Nonetheless, they undergo substantial volume changes during charging and discharging, posing challenges in forming stable SEI films for electrode protection. Therefore, it is imperative to investigate novel and promising materials as anode materials in LIBs. In recent years, materials based on 2D MOFs have been introduced as a promising class of anode materials for lithium-ion batteries. The following section specifically explores the use of pristine 2D MOFs, 2D MOF-derived materials, and 2D MOF composites as anodes in LIBs. 7.2.1 2D MOF-based materials as anode electrode: Pristine 2D MOFs In addition to their application as cathode materials, pristine 2D MOFs are anticipated to be suitable candidates for use as anode materials in LIBs [215]. This is attributed to their large surface area, and the redox activity of metal ions and organic ligands, which enable them to exhibit lithium storage capability. As a result, they demonstrate fewer issues such as severe volume fluctuation and sluggish ion transport kinetics, commonly encountered with many other types of anode materials. Several 2D MOF-based materials have been employed as both anodes and cathodes in LIBs (Table 1 ). Li et al. designed low-cost, high-energy ultrathin 2D MOF nanosheets (Mn-UMOFNs) for use as lithium-ion battery anode material [216]. The presence of Mn and BDC linker in lithium storage, and fully utilizing redox sites, led to excellent battery properties such as high reversible capacity and good rate capability with a columbic efficiency approaching (Fig. 18 a, b). Nazir et al. recently synthesized graphene analogue 2D Ni-MOF nanofilaments (2D Ni-MOF NFs) exhibiting high electronic conductivity and suitable porosity, subsequently employing them as anode material for lithium-ion batteries [217]. The high surface area of 2D Ni-MOF NFs provides a pathway for Li-ion diffusion, resulting in a remarkable specific capacity of 719 mA h g−1 even after 200 cycles at 1 A g−1, along with a high energy density of 248 Wh kg−1 at 1.4 A g−1 (Fig. 18c–e). One of the common challenges associated with using MOFs as anode materials in LIBs is their short lifespan and poor cycle stability. This issue can be partially addressed by activating 2D MOFs after synthesis. Low-temperature calcination activation of 2D MOFs can increase the specific surface area and improve porosity, thereby enhancing mass transfer and improving cycle stability. For instance, Liu et al. fabricated Co-MOF nanosheets via a solvothermal approach, followed by subsequent low-temperature calcination (Fig. 18f) [12]. The activation of the 2D flaky pristine Co-MOF delivers more active sites and a larger surface area, resulting in significant improvements in electrochemical performance when used as the anode of LIBs (1402.0 mA h g−1 at 0.5 A g−1 after 100 cycles and reaching 303.4 mA h g−1 after 700 cycles at 1.0 A g−1) (Fig. 18g). To increase the number of redox-active sites and enhance the structural stability of electrode materials, the careful selection of metals and ligands with excellent redox properties can be advantageous. Geng et al. selected iron (III) and TABQ, known for their favorable redox chemistry, to fabricate a stable framework of 2D MOF with remarkable specific capacity as an anode material in LIBs [6]. In this π–d conjugated 2D structure, Fe-N2O2 and phenylenediamine building blocks, with Fe-TABQ chains connected by several hydrogen bonds (Fig. 18h). The inherent robust Fe–N(O) bonds and enhanced Li–N(O) interactions during cycling play a serious role in the framework stability during electrochemical reactions. Additionally, the good obtained specific capacity and energy density is due to the dual redox properties of Fe ions and TABQ linkers. The obtained 2D framework per formula unit uptakes three Li+ ions and transfers three electrons via two charge and discharge steps. In the first step, Fe-TABQ nanosheets accept one electron and absorb one Li+ equivalent. In the second step, the unsaturated –C = O/–C = N bonds in ligand structure can transfer two electrons, resulting in the reduction to saturated –C–O–/C–N– bonds (Fig. 18i). An important factor that can limit the maximum potential of 2D MOFs in the field of LIB anodes is the selection of only one ligand in the structure of the 2D MOFs, which may restrict the availability of redox-active sites. Simultaneously incorporating two different types of ligands in the structure can optimize the lithium storage efficiency of 2D MOF-based electrode materials. However, synthesizing this type of MOFs is complicated. Recently, two types of chemically active ligands (HHTP, THQ) were used for the synthesis of a dual-ligand-based MOF with 2D nanosheet morphology by Yin and co-workers [218]. The resulting Cu3(HHTP)(THQ), owing to its excellent properties such as high conductivity, numerous active sites, and high chemical stability, is utilized as an anode material for LIBs. Lithium storage in this structure is facilitated by the CuO4 units and aromatic benzene rings in Cu3(HHTP)(THQ) resulting in delivering a reversible capacity of 624.8 mA h g−1 at 300 mA g−1 with an excellent coulombic efficiency (about 100%). In addition to the main ligand, incorporating a pillar ligand into the structure of 2D MOFs can introduce abundant space and channels for inserting and extracting lithium ions. On the other hand, these spaces and channels help mitigate volume expansion during the cycles. Also, the many channels created by the pillared structure of Co(BDC)TED0.5 can contribute to exposing more active sites and facilitate the transfer of Li ions within the material, as well as the storage of electrolyte. This is beneficial for enhancing the electrochemical performance of 2D MOFs. Additionally, the pillared ligand can stabilize the resulting framework at high temperatures and during cycling. A new pillared-layer MOF was synthesized by Mutahir et al. using TED as the pillar ligand and BDC as the main ligand via a facile hydrothermal method [219] (Fig. 19 a). The resulting Co(BDC)TED0.5 with brick-like porous structure, (Fig. 19b) was applied as an anode material for LIBs and exhibits good properties such as optimal capacities of 614 mA h g−1 at 0.2 A g−1 and good cycling performance at a current density of 1 A g−1 (Fig. 19c). Despite the benefits offered by redox-active materials as anode materials for LIBs, their poor electrical conductivity and high solubility in electrolytes present persistent challenges to device performance which can be addressed by integrating highly conductive, stable, and well-structured active sites within 2D MOFs. In this context, Yin et al. have introduced an innovative approach to synthesizing a dual redox-active site 2D MOF material featuring a HATN skeleton and CuO4 units (Fig. 20 a) [220]. This material presents a maximal number of active centers (Fig. 20b), high electrical conductivity (Fig. 20c), and efficient mass transfer channels. The ultra-high specific capacity, exceptional rate capability, and long-term cycling stability demonstrated by the synthesized materials (Fig. 20d) pave the way for the development of the next generation of high-performance LIBs. 7.2.2 2D MOF-based materials as anode electrode: 2D MOF-derived materials 2D MOF-derived materials such as Transition metal oxides (TMOs) and porous carbons obtained from pristine 2D MOFs as templates, having the porous structures of 2D MOF precursors and great electronic conductivities can be a good candidate as electrode materials in LIBs. Transition metal oxides can be produced through the calcination of 2D MOFs in the air, while pyrolysis in an inert atmosphere can yield porous carbon materials. TMOs, particularly Co3O4, have been identified as attractive materials for LIBs and supercapacitors due to their favorable properties such as high theoretical specific capacities, simple preparation, low cost, and stable electrochemical performance [143,153]. However, using bulk Co3O4 as anode materials in LIBs has disadvantages such as large volume change leading to material pulverization and poor cycling performance. Preparation of low-dimensional Co3O4 instead of bulk Co3O4 can overcome these problems by increasing their surface area and conductivity. Due to their unique structure, two-dimensional MOFs can serve as favorable templates for preparing Co3O4 nanosheets. Recently, a series of 2D MOF-derived materials have been synthesized and utilized in LIBs with exceptional performance [88,143,147,153,221]. Li et al. investigated the application of Co3O4 materials derived from 2D MOFs as anode materials in LIBs [147]. Initially, they synthesized cobalt-based MOF nanoplates (CoBDC) through interfacial diffusion, which were subsequently transformed into Co3O4 nanosheets. The obtained 2D Co3O4 exhibits a significant specific capacity of 1477 mA h g−1 at a current density of 100 mA g−1 after 160 cycles. This study indicates that Co3O4, as a derived material from 2D MOFs, has the potential to be used as a LIB electrode. However, there are challenges such as poor conductivity and large volume changes associated with using Co3O4 materials in LIBs. Some studies have indicated that constructing hybrid materials of Co3O4 is an effective way to address the above-mentioned issues and enhance the performance of these derived materials as electrodes in LIBs. Fang et al. synthesized hybrid materials of Co-based 2D MOF-derived Co3O4 nanosheets as anode material for LIBs [88]. They used a 3D electro-conductive substrate (Ni foam/carbon fiber) to grow derived Co3O4 nanosheets on it (Fig. 21 a). The authors found that the obtained leaf-like Co3O4 nanosheets grown on Ni foam/carbon fiber exhibit good cycling performance (Fig. 21b) due to the synergistic effect of the large surface areas and shortened Li-ion diffusion length of 2D porous leaf-like Co3O4 and the outstanding electrical conductivity of nickel foam. In another study, Fang et al. prepared hybrid bimetallic transition metal oxides (TMOs) (Co3O4/ZnO) nanosheets derived from bimetallic Co-Zn-based 2D MOFs and utilized them as anode materials for LIBs [153]. These 2D MOF-derived materials exhibit excellent electrochemical performances, including a good rate performance and cycle stability with a capacity retention of 95.6%, and initial coulombic efficiencies (ICEs) of 76.9%. (Fig. 21c, d) They found that the nanosheets of bimetallic Co3O4/ZnO create more electrochemically active sites than bimetallic pristine MOFs, thereby providing more desirable electrochemical performances. What is more, the homogeneous distribution of Co3O4 and ZnO nanosheets led to a decrease in volume changes during the charge and discharge processes. Recently, Zheng et al. prepared Napoleon-like (NL) Co3O4 nanomaterial derived from 2D layered Co-MOF and investigated it as an LIB anode material [83]. The porous properties of this derived material and the space between layers effectively decrease volume expansion. Porous carbon materials, another category of 2D MOF-derived materials, demonstrate significant potential in LiBs owing to their large specific surface area and abundant pore structure inherited from 2D MOFs [222]. These characteristics provide numerous accessible active sites for the insertion and removal of Li-ions, consequently addressing challenges such as shortened ion diffusion distances and issues with volume expansion of electrodes and electrolyte infiltration [223,224]. For an instance, porous carbon derived from 2D Cu-BDC MOF nanosheets, prepared using a template-combined thermal treatment method (Fig. 22 a), has exhibited a specific capacity of 690.4 mA h g−1 at a current density of 0.1 A g−1 (Fig. 22b) [225]. This impressive performance can be attributed to its mesoporous structures, which facilitate ion migration. The two-dimensional layered structure of 2D MOFs plays a crucial role in controlling the final structure and morphology of the derived carbon. Moreover, the hierarchical pore structure generated after pyrolysis also aids in mitigating irreversible damage to the electrode material during charging and discharging processes. 7.2.3 MOF- based materials as anode electrode: 2D MOF composites 2D MOF composite materials represent another category of 2D MOF-based materials suitable for use as active components in LIBs. Pristine 2D MOFs can be hybridized with other materials possessing exceptional properties, such as graphene, black phosphorus, silicon, metal nanoparticles, POMs, and other 2D materials, through methods like intercalation or surface coating, to produce 2D MOF composite materials. The synergistic effects between 2D MOFs and the mentioned nanomaterials can result in high electrical conductivity and exceptional electrochemical performance in lithium-ion batteries. Graphene materials have become one of the most applicable 2D materials in electrochemical fields because of their excellent electrical and chemical properties [226]. The formation of GO/MOF hybrid material results from the synergistic effects between the MOF (ultrahigh porosity, structural flexibility, selectivity, etc.) and GO (conductivity, light absorption, mechanical stability, etc.), which can improve the properties of both material types and make them promising electrode materials in batteries. Some researchers, such as Yan et al. [227], Jayaramulu et al. [43], and Meng et al. [228], have successfully synthesized 2D MOF/GO hybrid materials as Li storage electrode materials in LIBs. Their findings demonstrated enhanced lithium-ion diffusion kinetics and increased redox sites compared to pristine 2D MOFs and GO. One of the other attractive 2D materials for batteries specially LIBs with high theoretical capacity is black phosphorus (2596 mA h g−1) [229], which can be combined with pristine 2D MOF materials to form porous 2D MOF@BP nanocomposites with remarkable properties such as multiple redox-active sites and high-rate capability. Recently, Jin et al. synthesized a stable 2D MOF hybrid structure from few-layer black phosphorus (BP) and NiCo-based 2D MOF with good Li+ insertion sites (Fig. 23 a) and used as anode material for LIBs [176]. The prepared 2D BP/NiCo MOF exhibited optimal reversible capacity (853 mA h g−1 at 0.5 A g−1), and long cycle life (Fig. 23b). The stable structure of the BP/NiCo hybrid can be result in bonding of carboxylate groups BDC ligands as a building block of NiCo MOF with black phosphorus. Moreover, the enhanced electrochemical performance of BP/NiCo electrode can be attributed to several redox-active sites, high storage capability of lithium ions, and high structural porosity that led to desirable pathways for charge transport and limit the volume change during cycling. Silicon, with its attractive theoretical specific capacity (>3500 mA h) and low discharge potential (∼370 mV vs. Li/Li+), stands out as one of the most famous and promising materials utilized for anode materials in next-generation LIBs [230]. However, a significant challenge hampers the widespread use of these materials in LIBs. During the charge and discharge process, silicon undergoes volume expansion [231], leading to severe particle pulverization. Low electrical conductivity and the instability of the solid-electrolyte interphase (SEI) are other challenges Arising from repeated volume changes of the Si material, resulting in the deterioration of some electrochemical properties of LIBs [232]. To address these issues, various strategies have been proposed, such as controlling the size of Si particles to a nanoscale level and preparing hybrid materials of Si [233–237]. Intercalating Si particles into various porous materials, such as porous 2D MOFs, could enhance the electrochemical properties of Si anode materials and provide a solution for volume changes. The pores in the structure of 2D MOFs can serve as open channels, allowing the organic electrolyte to move inside these channels and toward the Si particles. The presence of 2D MOF around Si helps facilitate Li-ion diffusion by creating void spaces, thereby improving electronic conductivity. In addition, creating a hybrid material of silicon and 2D MOFs can also enhance the electrochemical properties of pristine 2D MOFs. Nazir et al. reported a 2D MOF composite containing silicon nanoparticles and a 2D Cu-based MOF as an anode material for high-capacity Li-ion batteries [167]. Specifically, they utilized the 2D CuMOF to enhance the electrochemical properties (Fig. 23c) and address the volume changes associated with Si-based anode materials in LIBs. Recently, POMs with favorable redox properties, have garnered attention as potential anode materials for LIBs [238–241].
