POMs, known for their structural stability during charge and discharge processes and redox activity, can enhance Li+ insertion/extraction and improve cycling capabilities [242]. However, low specific surface area, low stability under electrochemical reactions, low electronic conductivity resulting from the molecular metal-oxo structure, and solubility and partial degradation in the electrolyte have limited their performance as anode materials for LIBs [243–245]. Encapsulation of POMs in porous materials such as MOFs can be considered as one of the strategies to dominate these challenges. Yang et al. utilized 2D MOFs as support to incorporate POMs into their porous structure, creating a nanocomposite for application in LIBs as anode materials [184]. This nanocomposite, combining the excellent properties of both 2D MOFs and POMs, demonstrated good electrochemical performance as electrode materials in LIBs (Fig. 23d). MXene, exemplified by Ti3C2T x , has emerged as a prominent member among 2D materials, poised to excel as a high-performance electrode in both LIBs and SCs [246–248]. This is attributed to several advantageous characteristics, including a high surface-to-volume ratio, abundant active sites, negatively charged surfaces that reduce ion diffusion pathways, superior electronic conductivity, excellent hydrophilicity, and negligible volume change. Additionally, MXene offers large and tunable interlayer spaces, which further enhance electrochemical kinetics [249]. However, the practical application of MXene in LIBs is strongly limited by its low theoretical capacitance and issues related to restacking [250]. Yet, by offering more chemically active interfaces and shortened ion-diffusion lengths, MXene can effectively alleviate the unbalanced ion kinetics between the anode and cathode [251]. Furthermore, the utilization of 2D MOFs in LIBs is still impeded by the unfavorable Li+ adsorption energy (ΔE a), potentially leading to the formation of Li clusters and irreversible Li diffusion [47]. Scientists have discovered that designing advanced composite electrode materials from 2D MOFs and MXene enhances the interaction between MXene and 2D MOFs, significantly increasing the DEa. Introducing MXene to 2D MOFs can effectively optimize the electronic structures and DEa of the resulting nanocomposite. Sun et al. developed a nanocomposite based on 2D Ni-ferrocene dicarboxylic MOF (NF-MOF) and MXene to create stable anodes for Li+ storage [47]. The NF-MOF@MXene composite exhibited significantly enhanced rate performance (620 mA h g−1 at 1 A g−1) compared to the NF-MOF electrode, along with exceptional cycling stability (80% capacity retention at 5 A g−1 after 5000 cycles) (Fig. 23e). This study underscores the importance of improving ΔE a through substantial charge redistribution at the interfaces, transferring from MXene to MOF layers. The development of conductive MOF@MXene heterostructures for enhanced LIBs can provide deeper insights into the development of advanced composite materials as electrode for energy storage systems. Carbon nanotubes have attracted considerable attention for their potential applications in LIBs due to their unique structural, electrical, and mechanical properties, which offer improved performance and scalability [252]. Integrating CNTs with 2D MOFs to prepare anode electrodes for LIBs has resulted in enhanced energy storage performance compared to each material individually. This combination increases the exposed pore structure and specific surface area, facilitating high ion/electron transportation. Additionally, it promotes effective exfoliation and dispersion of the MOF layered structure, preventing the formation of tightly-stacked 2D MOFs. Recently, a flaky 2D MOF-CNT composite, prepared using an in-situ intercalation method (Fig. 24 a–c), has been employed as an anode electrode for LIB, demonstrating significantly enhanced reversible capacity (1451 mA h g−1 for LIBs after 100 cycles at 100 mA g−1) (Fig. 24d, e) [253]. The presence of highly conductive CNTs in this composite provides numerous activated electrochemical sites and improves electrochemical reaction kinetics effectively. 8 The compatibility of 2D MOF-based electrode materials with electrolyte The compatibility of 2D MOF materials with electrolyte is crucial to their application in lithium-ion batteries. In particular, anode materials in lithium-ion batteries require excellent compatibility with the electrolyte to ensure optimal performance and safety. The compatibility of 2D MOFs with electrolyte influences ion transport within the battery system, directly impacting the battery's power output and overall performance. Additionally, compatibility with electrolyte affects the structural stability of 2D MOFs in batteries. Moreover, the compatibility between the electrolyte and the anode material is crucial for the formation of a stable solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) layer, which is essential for battery performance. A stable interface between the MOF electrode and the electrolyte is vital for preventing the formation of an unstable SEI layer, maintaining structural integrity, and ensuring long-term cycling stability of the battery, thereby leading to high coulombic efficiency. As such, it is imperative to design 2D MOFs with good electrolyte compatibility. One effective strategy is to combine MOF electrode materials with other nanomaterials that exhibit good conductivity. This combination can prevent the possible stacking and instability of 2D MOF structures, which can hinder the contact of active centers with the electrolyte and decrease the diffusion rate of lithium ions. For example, to improve electron transport and enhance the compatibility between the electrode and the electrolyte, a novel Cu-based conductive metal–organic framework composite (Cu-HHTP/G) was synthesized using HHTP as a ligand, with graphene added during the synthesis process (Fig. 25 a) [254]. The composite showed a network of Cu-HHTP uniformly dispersed on graphene layers. (Fig. 25b, c) In the Cu-HHTP MOF structure, both copper ions and aromatic rings of the ligand formed lithiation/delithiation sites, participating in the lithium storage mechanism (Fig. 25d). The intermolecular forces between graphene layers and Cu-HHTP led to a continuous 2D conductive network with a large number of active sites in contact with the electrolyte. The results showed that pristine MOF had inadequate contact with the electrolyte due to the instability and stacking of the structure, especially during the initial cycle, which led to low initial cycle efficiency. As a result, the higher porosity and more exposed surface of Cu-HHTP/G compared with pristine Cu-HHTP resulted in better electrochemical performances, achieving 1086 mA h g−1 for LIBs at 0.1 C after 300 cycles. (Fig. 25e). Another strategy that can enhance the compatibility of 2D MOF electrode materials with electrolytes is the fabrication of 2D MOF-derived materials like transition metal oxides, which can significantly enhance conductivity and stability, thereby improving compatibility with electrolytes. Creating a 3D network structure, such as forming fiber composites of 2D MOF materials through methods like spinning, can enhance interfacial interactions between MOFs and electrolytes, providing efficient paths for rapid Li+ transport. This approach can promote cation transfer and improve the uniformity of ion migration, enhancing the compatibility of 2D MOFs with electrolytes. Additionally, when 2D MOFs are used as electrodes in lithium-ion batteries, various electrolytes such as liquid electrolytes, solid-state electrolytes, and gel polymer electrolytes can be employed. Designing suitable electrolytes that offer enhanced ion transport, chemical stability, compatibility with MOF structure, safety, and environmental considerations is promising for use with 2D MOFs in batteries. However, designing 2D MOFs with high compatibility with electrolytes and choosing a compatible electrolyte requires extensive research and investigation to optimize the battery performance. 9 Comparative performance and practical applications of 2D MOF-based materials in lithium-ion batteries Various types of 2D MOFs, encompassing pristine, derived and composite, are being used as electrodes in LIBs, each providing opportunities to improve the energy storage and retention performance of batteries. The dual role of these materials as both cathode and anode electrodes in LIBs has been evaluated in Table 1, which investigates key performance metrics such as specific capacity, cycling stability, and initial coulombic efficiency in recent studies. Among different types of 2D MOFs, pristine materials have been employed as both cathode and anode electrodes, setting them apart from other categories of 2D MOF-based materials. The controlled synthesis methods used to produce these materials have enabled the optimization of their electrochemical properties, making them efficient electrode materials. Furthermore, it can be observed that by using composite methods and derivatization, the performance of pure 2 materials can be enhanced while maintaining their unique properties. This improvement increases their suitability for battery applications. Each type of 2D MOFs exhibits unique characteristics, resulting in both advantages and disadvantages for their application as cathodes and anodes, as summarized in Fig. 26 . From the perspective of cathode electrodes, the tunable high degree of porosity, increased number of active centers, and cost-effectiveness compared to traditional materials make 2D pristine MOFs promising candidates. The perfectly accessible oxidation of both metals and ligands provides high specific capacities and good cycling stability for these materials as cathode electrodes. Due to their exceptional performance, further investigations are needed to enhance the applicability of 2D pristine MOFs for industrial purposes. As anode electrodes, 2D MOF-based materials have demonstrated high specific capacities and excellent cycling stability, making them attractive candidates for enhancing the energy storage capacity and efficiency of lithium-ion batteries. Their unique structural properties and tunable pore sizes contribute to improved lithium-ion diffusion kinetics and enhanced electrochemical performance. These enhancements can be achieved through the controllable synthesis of 2D structures in pristine MOFs, pure sheets obtained from 2D MOF-derived structures, or higher-order dimensionality in composite materials. As presented in Table 1, composite materials used as anode electrodes offer enhanced performance in specific capacity compared to other types of 2D MOFs, making them the best choice for this application. This advantage is attributed to the synergistic effect resulting from the addition of an active component to the structure of two-dimensional materials. This synergistic effect significantly impacts structural properties, including an increase in surface area, which directly contributes to substantial improvements in specific capacity. Composite materials also outperform pristine and 2D MOF-derived materials in cyclic stability. The incorporation of active components in 2D MOF composites enhances the structural stability of the material, leading to reduced volume expansion and degradation over multiple charge-discharge cycles. On the other hand, improvements in efficiency can be observed in 2D MOF-derived materials used as anode electrodes. This advantage is due to the absence of organic ligands in the 2D derived structure, which eliminates electrostatic interactions between lithium ions and electron-rich organic ligands, resulting in a more efficient lithium extraction. These findings highlight the distinct roles of each type of 2D MOF when employed as cathode and anode electrodes in LIBs. It is important to note that these results are based on existing research findings, and further studies are necessary in this field to draw definitive conclusions and expand our understanding. 10 2D MOF-based material preparation and their applications in Li-ion batteries: Challenges and perspective Although many remarkable achievements have been realized in 2D MOFs, there are still remaining challenges that must be addressed before their use in practical applications. • One of the primary limitations of using pristine 2D MOFs as electrode materials in LIBs is their structural instability during lithiation and dilatation. Creating a stable framework involves selecting appropriate ligands and metals capable of forming strong coordination bonds, along with designing a robust network structure can enhance the stability of 2D MOFs as electrode materials in LIBs. Developing novel electrolytes represents another strategy to mitigate the instability issues associated with 2D MOFs. The use of gel electrolytes or solid-state electrolyte with can also be considered to attain better device stabilities. Therefore, exploring methods to improve the intrinsic stability of these 2D MOFs through creating the strong coordination and a suitable electrode-electrolyte interface is crucial. • Furthermore, MOF materials often exhibit low coulombic efficiency in the initial cycles when used as electrode materials in LIBs. The chemical structure of MOFs can be an effective factor contributing to the low initial coulombic efficiency. The formation of strong electrostatic interactions between the electron-rich ligands in the MOF structure and Li+ during the first discharge may lead to the irreversibly “captured” Li+, resulting in less extraction of Li+ during the initial charge [258]. In addition, during the first lithiation cycle, MOFs can undergo irreversible reactions with the electrolyte, leading to the formation of solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) layer and reduced coulombic efficiency, particularly during the initial charge–discharge cycles [259]. Moreover, the incorporation of lithium ions into the MOF structure can cause structural rearrangements that may not be fully reversible during delithiation, resulting in capacity loss. To improve the initial coulombic efficiency of MOF-based electrodes, strategies such as surface coatings, pre-lithiation, and optimizing the MOF structure and composition are being investigated. Some results indicate that 2D MOF materials have higher initial coulombic efficiency compared to their 3D counterparts. 2D MOFs typically have a more accessible structure with a higher surface area, allowing for better initial lithium-ion intercalation and extraction processes, leading to higher coulombic efficiency in the initial cycles compared to 3D MOFs. Additionally, the 2D structure of MOFs provides shorter diffusion pathways for lithium ions, enabling faster and more efficient ion transport during the initial cycles, which contributes to the higher coulombic efficiency observed. Besides, the 2D nature of MOFs allows for more intimate contact between the electrode and electrolyte, enhancing the initial electrochemical reactions and resulting in higher coulombic efficiency in the early cycles. These factors collectively contribute to the higher coulombic efficiency observed in the initial cycles of 2D MOFs compared to 3D MOFs in lithium-ion batteries. However, more investigation in this area is necessary to fully understand and optimize these materials for practical applications. • The integration of 2D MOFs with other materials can, in principle, enhance structural stability, increase active sites, and improve mass transfer rates. However, this combination can sometimes lead to the decomposition (structural collapse) or inhomogeneity of 2D MOFs. Thus, effective methods for combining MOFs with other materials to form 2D MOF nanocomposites must be developed. Optimizing the relationship between structures/compositions and corresponding electrochemical properties is essential for further enhancement. Additionally, understanding the fundamental mechanisms involved in the electrochemical processes, particularly for 2D MOF composites, remains a challenge that requires more research efforts. Moreover, the detailed physical and chemical processes involved in the conversion from 2D MOF precursors to 2D MOF-derived materials are still unclear. • Boosting electrical conductivity is a vital factor for the successful application of 2D MOF frameworks as electrode materials in LIBs. To overcome conductivity constraints and fulfill conductivity prerequisites, strategies such as the use of redox-active ligands or the integration of molecules with numerous active sites into the network have demonstrated potential in specific instances. • Since different 2D MOFs exhibit distinct conduction and energy storage mechanisms, exploring these mechanisms is vital for further advancements in the field. Moreover, our understanding of the mechanical properties and degradation patterns of 2D MOFs remains limited. This knowledge gap necessitates the need for comprehensive studies to address these aspects, which are crucial for optimizing the performance and cycle life of these materials in practical energy storage applications. • The high cost of certain ligands and the complexity of synthesis methods pose challenges for the widespread application of 2D MOFs in practical battery systems. Therefore, it is imperative to investigate low-cost ligands for the fabrication of 2D MOF-based materials and explore novel, cost-effective synthesis strategies for these materials. By using raw materials of the secondary nature (like those attainable from low-grade sources, metal wastes, etc.) can overcome to this challenge. • The mechanisms underlying lithium storage in 2D MOFs remain ambiguous, necessitating the application of in-situ advanced characterization techniques for deeper insights. Therefore, further theoretical calculations and experimental studies are necessary to engineer 2D MOFs with controllable morphology and compositions as electrode materials and to understand the lithium storage mechanism of MOFs more comprehensively. Indeed, it is imperative to discover robust techniques for enhanced characterization of 2D MOFs and to decipher the intricate relationship between electrochemical performance and the structure of these materials. • Density functional theory (DFT) calculations play an important role in the development of various new organic ligands and in guiding the synthesis of novel 2D MOFs. Continuous innovation is necessary to enhance the properties and applications of 2D MOFs. Besides their use in lithium batteries, 2D MOFs hold promise for applications in other alkali metal batteries (such as sodium-ion batteries and potassium-ion batteries) and multivalent metal-ion batteries (including zinc-ion batteries and magnesium-ion batteries) and supercapacitors. Despite their current applications, 2D MOFs still have immense potential for further development in this field. We anticipate that research and applications of 2D MOFs in electrochemical energy storage and conversion will continue to expand in the future. On a final note, the yet-to-be-explored potential of fabricating 3D structures, such as fibers and yarns, using solution processing methods from pure 2D MOFs, presents a promising avenue. This approach could lead to the manufacturing of interesting architectures with a vast range of applications. The exploration of these possibilities is crucial for unlocking the full potential of these materials in practical applications. To conclude, energy storage applications of MOFs and MOF inspired structures are still at the lab scale, and they remain in the early stages of development. Further research efforts in this enormous field will contribute to the extension of MOF research in the development of the next generation of clean and green energy storage systems. From an application standpoint, while 2D MOF composites demonstrate significant potential for lithium-ion battery applications, their performance has yet to meet expectations. Consequently, further efforts are required to enhance their performance. 11 Conclusions While 2D MOF-based materials, known for their high activity and stability, have attracted considerable attention recently, they still remain in the early stages of development. These materials boast superior attributes compared to their 1D and 3D MOF counterparts, including greater access to active sites and improved performance. The intrinsic properties of 2D MOFs, such as their extensive specific surface area, porous architecture, and elevated electrical conductivity, enhance the availability of active and lithium storage sites, thereby fostering ion migration within Lithium-Ion Batteries. Comparing various 2D MOF-based materials aimed at improving lithium battery electrode performance reveals the advantages of transitioning to hybrid and derived structures of 2D pristine MOFs. These structures offer increased active metal sites through synergistic effects among components, leading to more efficient electrode materials for lithium-ion batteries. While direct use of 2D pristine MOFs as electrode materials reduces costs associated with composite fabrication and derivatives, advancements in synthesis methods are required to yield higher quality and more affordable two-dimensional materials, making them one of the most promising candidates poised to change the future of energy storage. Besides, the quest for novel MOFs characterized by low cost, high conductivity, and desirable stability is crucial for advancing their real development as battery materials in advanced batteries. Understanding the conduction and energy storage mechanisms of electrode materials is essential for controlling the synthesis of 2D MOF electrodes and enhancing battery performance. Since different 2D MOFs exhibit distinct conduction and energy storage mechanisms, exploring these mechanisms is vital for further advancements in the field. Moreover, our understanding of the mechanical properties and degradation patterns of 2D MOFs remains limited. This knowledge gap necessitates the need for comprehensive studies to address these aspects, which are crucial for optimizing the performance and cycle life of these materials in practical energy storage applications. Narges Nobakht is a Postdoctoral Researcher in Condensed Matter National Laboratory of Institute for Research in Fundamental Sciences (IPM), with a Doctor of Philosophy (PhD) focused in nano chemistry. She is co-founder of BattScout, an independent battery consulting start-up company specialized in researching and analyzing scientific and patent information in materials science and energy storage. Her current research interests are focused on design of new nanostructured materials for biological and energy applications. Seyyed Ahmad Etghani is a postdoctoral fellow at the Institute for Research in Fundamental Sciences (IPM). He holds Bachelor's and master's degrees in electrical engineering from K.N. Toosi University. He completed his Ph.D. at the University of Tehran, specializing in semiconductor devices. He is the founder of a company in the field of biosensors and Lab on a Chip devices. His expertise covers a wide range of topics relating to sensor fabrication, bioelectronic devices, energy devices, biomaterials and 2D materials synthesis and characterization. Mohammad Hosseini (ORCID: 0000-0001-9221-5735) was born in Tehran in 1987. He received his Ph.D. in electrical engineering from the University of Tehran, Iran. Currently, he serves as a postdoctoral fellow at the Institute for Research in Fundamental Sciences (IPM). His research interests include nano/micro-electrical device fabrication, energy devices, nano-biosensors, light emission from nanostructures and synthesis and characterization of two-dimensional materials. Seyed Hamed Aboutalebi (ORCID: 0000-0002-3711-332X) works as an associate professor in Condensed Matter National Laboratory, Institute for Research in Fundamental Sciences (IPM). Before joining IPM, he earned his Ph.D. from the Institute for Superconducting and Electronic Materials (ISEM), Australian Institute for Innovative Materials (AIIM), University of Wollongong in 2014. From 2010 to 2016, he collaborated with the Illawarra Health and Medical Research Institute (IHMRI), Intelligent Polymer Research Institute, and the Materials Node of the Australian National Fabrication Facility (ANFF), as well as the ARC Center of Excellence for Electro Materials Science (ACES). His research during this period focused on various aspects of 2D materials synthesis and processing, and the subsequent additive manufacturing processing of soft 2D materials pioneered the discovery of liquid crystal dispersion of different 2D materials in various dispersing agents.

coredata.dc:description: Two-dimensional (2D) metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are rapidly emerging as a unique class of mushrooming family of 2D materials offering distinctive features, such as hierarchical porosity, extensive surface area, easily available active sites, and versatile, adaptable structures. These promising characteristics have positioned them as highly appealing alternatives for a wide range of applications in energy storage technologies, including lithium batteries. Nevertheless, the poor conductivity and limited stability of 2D MOFs have limited their real applications in electrochemical energy storage. These limitations have therefore warranted ongoing research to enhance the performance of 2D MOFs. Given the significance of 2D MOF-based materials as an emerging class of advanced materials, a multitude of strategy has been devised to address these challenges such as synthesizing 2D conductive MOFs and derivatives along with 2D MOF hybridization. One promising approach involves the use of 2D MOF derivatives, including transition metal oxides, which due to their abundant unsaturated active metal sites and shorter diffusion paths, offer superior electrochemical performance. Additionally, by combining pristine 2D MOFs with other materials, hybrid 2D MOF materials can be created. These hybrids, with their enhanced stability and conductivity, can be directly utilized as active materials in lithium batteries. In the present review, we categorize 2D MOF-based materials into three distinct groups: pristine 2D MOFs, 2D MOF-derived materials, and 2D MOF hybrid materials. The synthesis methods for each group, along with their specific applications as electrode materials in lithium-ion batteries, are discussed in detail. This comprehensive review provides insights into the potential of 2D MOFs while highlighting the opportunities and challenges that are present in this evolving field.
